title: Quarters in service wing, 1850s
headline: Indian Range, 1012 Mount Airy Road, Davidsonville, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Two-story house built on a large rural estate in a design at least inspired by the work of Downing and Davis. Constructed about 1850. Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from teh unheated quarter to the second floor of the house.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: house,dwelling,a j davis,downing,davis and downing,frame,timber frame,gothic,gothic revival,quarter,slave quarter,slave,enslave,chamber,attic,plaster,window,dormer

title: Cast-iron butt hinge, ca. 1805
headline: Ellerslie, Bacon's Castle Trail, Surry County, Virginia
description: Two-story frame house, center passage plan. Mix of hand-forged wrought-iron nails and double struck machine cut nails. Lath nails are cut with flat heads. Riven lath. Georgian-style moldings. Cast-iron butt hinges except for a pair of H hinges on door under stair. CLosed string stair with square balusters. Thin muntins. Wainscot in most rooms--mix of flat, recessed panels and raised panels. Double chimneys on both ends connected to each other but pierced with a central window on the first floor and a cellar entry on the east side.3/1 American bond foundations and chimney. Hewn and pit sawn timbers; gauged and undercut flooring. c. 1805. Door to attic; original cast-iron butt hinges. Each leaf marked with 2 punches
creator: Willie Graham

headline: Cloverfields, 500 Forman Landing Road, Queenstown, Queen Anne's County, Maryland
description: Built 1705; expanded 1728; rear rooms raised two stories in 1750s; roof of rear converted to a shed in 1761; house renovated in 1769; heavily remodeled in the 1840s; remodeled again in 1912. restored 2018-2021. 1705 staircase. 1769 arch and passage
creator: Willie Graham

title: Mattaponi Baptist Church
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: church,brick,masonry,david minetree,minetree,flemish bond,glaszed header,all glazed header flemish bond

title: Recreated hyphen, 1784
headline: Cloverfields, 500 Forman Landing Road, Queenstown, Queen Anne's County, Maryland
description: Built 1705; expanded 1728; rear rooms raised two stories in 1750s; roof of rear converted to a shed in 1761; house renovated in 1769; heavily remodeled in the 1840s; remodeled again in 1912. restored 2018-2021. Reconstruction of 1782-84 hyphen (referred to as the passage inm teh 1798 Direct Tax). Physical investigations by Willie Graham; excavations by Archaeology of Annapolis. Built by Lynbrook of Annapolis.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Window mullion brick
headline: Gripsholm Castle, 647 31 Mariefred, Södermanland, Sweden
description: From Wikipedia: In 1773, Gripsholm Castle was renovated by King Gustav III,[8] on behalf of his consort Sophia Magdalena. The castle was frequently used by the royal court during the reign of Gustav III, who favored it and spent several months there every year. The perhaps most famous addition to the castle during his reign was a theater, which was added in one of the castle towers. It was the stage for both the amateur theatre of the royal court as well as The French Theater of Gustav III in 1781–1792. After the Coup of 1809, Gustav IV Adolf and his family were also imprisoned in the castle after his deposition from the throne. He had to sign his abdication document there. Labeled ribbed brick 1500s,  presumably from a leaded window in a brick building
creator: Willie Graham

title: 1654 almshouse on alley
location: House of Our Lady of Woes
headline: House of Our Lady of Seven Woes, Driekroezenstraat 2-8, Bruge, West Flanders, Belgium
description: Former almshouses seemingly constructed in 1654. Located on the corner with Oude Gentweg 8. Former alms house O.-L.-V. VAN DE ZEVEN WEEËN / 1654 see painted inscription. Existing houses purchased in 1653 by founders Maria de Damhouder and Joost van der Straeten and furnished as a house of worship in 1654-1655, see partly weathered gable stone with (almost illegible) date 1654 as the keystone of the door frame. In 1951: adaptation of the original, high-placed windows to the current ones. 1979: conversion of houses into four residential units by architect E. Vyncke. https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/81852
creator: Willie Graham
categories: almshouse,poor house,godshuis,alley,alleyway,gable,cross gable,stepped gable,tie,wall tie,brick,masonry,dwelling,dutch gable

headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham

title: Mattaponi Baptist Church
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: church,brick,masonry,david minetree,minetree,flemish bond,glazed header,all glazed header flemish bond

headline: Gripsholm Castle, 647 31 Mariefred, Södermanland, Sweden
description: From Wikipedia: In 1773, Gripsholm Castle was renovated by King Gustav III,[8] on behalf of his consort Sophia Magdalena. The castle was frequently used by the royal court during the reign of Gustav III, who favored it and spent several months there every year. The perhaps most famous addition to the castle during his reign was a theater, which was added in one of the castle towers. It was the stage for both the amateur theatre of the royal court as well as The French Theater of Gustav III in 1781–1792. Stucco rendered to appear as rubbed brick on tower. After the Coup of 1809, Gustav IV Adolf and his family were also imprisoned in the castle after his deposition from the throne. He had to sign his abdication document there.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: castle,tower,brick,masonry,stucco,stucco to resemble brick,brick patterned stucco

title: Bowfat in cellar moved from across the room, 1764
headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham
categories: rococco,georgian,classical,5 part house,dwelling,house,plantation,sharpe horation sharpe,gov. sharpe,basement,dining room,beaufat,carve,carving,glaze,glazed door,shell

headline: Gripsholm Castle, 647 31 Mariefred, Södermanland, Sweden
description: From Wikipedia: In 1773, Gripsholm Castle was renovated by King Gustav III,[8] on behalf of his consort Sophia Magdalena. The castle was frequently used by the royal court during the reign of Gustav III, who favored it and spent several months there every year. The perhaps most famous addition to the castle during his reign was a theater, which was added in one of the castle towers. It was the stage for both the amateur theatre of the royal court as well as The French Theater of Gustav III in 1781–1792. After the Coup of 1809, Gustav IV Adolf and his family were also imprisoned in the castle after his deposition from the throne. He had to sign his abdication document there. 1802 drawing of theater
creator: Willie Graham

title: 1850s country house inspired by Davis and Downing
headline: Indian Range, 1012 Mount Airy Road, Davidsonville, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Two-story house built on a large rural estate in a design at least inspired by the work of Downing and Davis. Constructed about 1850. Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from teh unheated quarter to the second floor of the house.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: house,dwelling,a j davis,downing,davis and downing,frame,timber frame,gothic,gothic revival,porch,gable

headline: Church of Our Lady, Bruges, West Flanders, Belgium
description: Dates mainly from the 13th, 14th and 15th centuries; third largest brick tower in Europe. Includes a sculptur of Maddona and Child by Michaelangelo. Painting of the church by Hendrik van Minderhout, 1701-1710, before its baroque makeover. Rood screen from about 1600.
creator: Willie Graham

headline: Indian Range, 1012 Mount Airy Road, Davidsonville, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Two-story house built on a large rural estate in a design at least inspired by the work of Downing and Davis. Constructed about 1850. Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from the unheated quarter to the second floor of the house. Leibrandt & McDowell Stove Company. Philadelphia & Baltimore.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: house,dwelling,a j davis,downing,davis and downing,frame,timber frame,gothic,kitchen,service,service wing,gothic revival,stove,leibrandt & mcdowell stove company,cast iron,cook,cokking,service

headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham

title: Gauged-and-rubbed work on the frontispiece
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Header bond construction; 1763
headline: St. James, Lothian, 5757 Solomons Island Road, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Built 1763; porch tower likely original construction; church remodeled mid 19th century. Mollie Ridout notes: Col. John Weems was the builder/contractor who oversaw the construction of the church. He owned 4 or 5 properties including Burrage’s End near the traffic circle in Harwood. All sold to pay debts when he died.

title: Night view across the water to Kungsholmen island
headline: City Hall, Hantverkargatan 1, 111 52, Stockholm, Sweden
description: From Wikipedia: In 1907, the city council decided to build a new city hall at the former site of Eldkvarn. An architectural design competition was held, which first resulted in the selection of drafts by Ragnar Östberg, Carl Westman, Ivar Tengbom jointly with Ernst Torulf, and Carl Bergsten. After a further competition between Westman and Östberg, the latter was assigned the construction of the City Hall, while the former was asked to build Stockholm Court House. Östberg modified his original draft using elements of Westman's design, including the tower. During construction, Östberg constantly reworked his plans, resulting in the addition of the lantern on top of the tower, and the abandonment of the blue glazed tiles in the Blue Hall. Oskar Asker was employed as construction leader and Paul Toll, of builders Kreuger & Toll, designed the foundations. Georg Greve also assisted in preparing the plans.[3] Construction took twelve years, from 1911 to 1923. Nearly eight million red bricks were used. The dark red bricks, called munktegel (monks's brick) because of their traditional use in the construction of monasteries and churches, were provided by Lina brickworks of Södertälje. The building was inaugurated on 23 June 1923, exactly 400 years after Gustav Vasa's arrival in Stockholm. Verner von Heidenstam and Hjalmar Branting delivered the inaugurational speeches.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Model of castle theatre
headline: Gripsholm Castle, 647 31 Mariefred, Södermanland, Sweden
description: From Wikipedia: In 1773, Gripsholm Castle was renovated by King Gustav III,[8] on behalf of his consort Sophia Magdalena. The castle was frequently used by the royal court during the reign of Gustav III, who favored it and spent several months there every year. The perhaps most famous addition to the castle during his reign was a theater, which was added in one of the castle towers. It was the stage for both the amateur theatre of the royal court as well as The French Theater of Gustav III in 1781–1792. After the Coup of 1809, Gustav IV Adolf and his family were also imprisoned in the castle after his deposition from the throne. He had to sign his abdication document there.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Chief's House, built about 1885, before restoration
headline: Chief's House, Sunnyside Road, St. Stephen's Church Vicinity, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Built about 1885 as a two-room, board-and-batten structure. Weatherboard, detached, frame kitchen built soon thereafter. About 1920 the kitchen was expanded and a front added tothe house, which connected it to the kitchen.Attic over the ca. 1920 extension; common rafter with a ridge board. Follows the 12/12 pitche of the adjoining, earlier section

headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham
categories: rococco,georgian,classical,5 part house,dwelling,house,plantation,sharpe horation sharpe,gov. sharpe,parlor,mantel,chimneypiece,mantel piece,marble,carve,carving,shelf,entablature,chair board

title: Interior
headline: Ellerslie, Bacon's Castle Trail, Surry County, Virginia
description: Two-story frame house, center passage plan. Mix of hand-forged wrought-iron nails and double struck machine cut nails. Lath nails are cut with flat heads. Riven lath. Georgian-style moldings. Cast-iron butt hinges except for a pair of H hinges on door under stair. CLosed string stair with square balusters. Thin muntins. Wainscot in most rooms--mix of flat, recessed panels and raised panels. Double chimneys on both ends connected to each other but pierced with a central window on the first floor and a cellar entry on the east side.3/1 American bond foundations and chimney. Hewn and pit sawn timbers; gauged and undercut flooring. c. 1805. Second floor bedchamber, west, rear. Door to front chmaber added in 20th century.
creator: Willie Graham

creator: Willie Graham

headline: Riddarholmen Church, Birger Jarls Torg 2, 112 28, Stockholm, Sweden
description: From Wikipedia: Riddarholmen Church (Swedish: Riddarholmskyrkan) is the church of the former medieval Greyfriars Monastery in Stockholm, Sweden. The church serves as the final resting place of most Swedish monarchs. Riddarholmen Church is located on the island of Riddarholmen, close to the Royal Palace in Stockholm, Sweden. The congregation was dissolved in 1807 and today the church is used only for burial and commemorative purposes. Swedish monarchs from Gustavus Adolphus (d. 1632 AD) to Gustaf V (d. 1950) are entombed here (with only one exception: Queen Christina who is buried within St. Peter's Basilica in Rome), as well as the earlier monarchs Magnus III (d. 1290) and Charles VIII (d. 1470). It has been discontinued as a royal burial site in favor of the Royal Cemetery and today is run by departments of the Swedish Government and Royal Court. It is one of the oldest buildings in Stockholm, parts of it dating to the late-13th century, when it was built as a greyfriars monastery. After the Protestant Reformation, the monastery was closed and the building became a Lutheran church. A spire designed by Flemish architect Willem Boy (1520–1592) was added during the reign of John III, but it was destroyed by a lightning strike on July 28, 1835, after which it was replaced with the present cast-iron spire.  Coats of arms of knights of the Royal Order of the Seraphim are on the walls of the church. When a knight of the Order dies, his coat of arms is hung in the church and when the funeral takes place the church's bells are rung without pause from 12:00 to 13:00.
creator: Willie Graham

title: 1654 almshouse on alley
location: House of Our Lady of Woes
headline: House of Our Lady of Seven Woes, Driekroezenstraat 2-8, Bruge, West Flanders, Belgium
description: Former almshouses seemingly constructed in 1654. Located on the corner with Oude Gentweg 8. Former alms house O.-L.-V. VAN DE ZEVEN WEEËN / 1654 see painted inscription. Existing houses purchased in 1653 by founders Maria de Damhouder and Joost van der Straeten and furnished as a house of worship in 1654-1655, see partly weathered gable stone with (almost illegible) date 1654 as the keystone of the door frame. In 1951: adaptation of the original, high-placed windows to the current ones. 1979: conversion of houses into four residential units by architect E. Vyncke. https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/81852
creator: Willie Graham

description: Built as a timber-frame dwelling from timbers cut in 1698; expanded in 1713 (also a dendro date). Brick T added as final phase of Samuel Harrison's work, the expansion recorded in a painting he commissioned before his death in 1733. At the same time, Harrison bricked the front face and gable end of the original wing and its extension. Front of original wing
creator: Willie Graham

title: Kitchen with remains of early stove
headline: Indian Range, 1012 Mount Airy Road, Davidsonville, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Two-story house built on a large rural estate in a design at least inspired by the work of Downing and Davis. Constructed about 1850. Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from the unheated quarter to the second floor of the house. Leibrandt & McDowell Stove Company. Philadelphia & Baltimore.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: house,dwelling,a j davis,downing,davis and downing,frame,timber frame,gothic,kitchen,service,service wing,gothic revival,stove,leibrandt & mcdowell stove company,cast iron,cook,cokking,service

title: Guaged-and-rubbed work of the frontispiece
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: church,brick,masonry,david minetree,minetree,all glazed header,flemish,flemish bond,header,glazed header,frontispiece,pediment,restored,rubbed brick,rubbed,gauged,gauged brick,gauged and rubbed brick

title: Cast-iron butt hinges secured with rose head nails; ca. 1805
headline: Ellerslie, Bacon's Castle Trail, Surry County, Virginia
description: Two-story frame house, center passage plan. Mix of hand-forged wrought-iron nails and double struck machine cut nails. Lath nails are cut with flat heads. Riven lath. Georgian-style moldings. Cast-iron butt hinges except for a pair of H hinges on door under stair. CLosed string stair with square balusters. Thin muntins. Wainscot in most rooms--mix of flat, recessed panels and raised panels. Double chimneys on both ends connected to each other but pierced with a central window on the first floor and a cellar entry on the east side.3/1 American bond foundations and chimney. Hewn and pit sawn timbers; gauged and undercut flooring. c. 1805. Unusual way to set butt hinges. Despite fasteners possibly dating to modern times, the orientation of the hinges and method of attachment appear to be original. Cast-iron butt hinge.Door from passage to rear, west room, floor 1.
creator: Willie Graham

headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham
categories: rococco,georgian,classical,5 part house,dwelling,house,plantation,sharpe horation sharpe,gov. sharpe,monument,grounds,landscape,garden

title: Guaged-and-rubbed work of the frontispiece
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: church,brick,masonry,david minetree,minetree,all glazed header,flemish,flemish bond,header,glazed header,frontispiece,pediment,restored,rubbed brick,rubbed,gauged,gauged brick,gauged and rubbed brick

creator: Willie Graham

title: Guaged-and-rubbed work of the frontispiece
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: church,brick,masonry,david minetree,minetree,all glazed header,flemish,flemish bond,header,glazed header,frontispiece,pediment,restored,rubbed brick,rubbed,gauged,gauged brick,gauged and rubbed brick

headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham

title: Square-butt shingle
headline: Indian Range, 1012 Mount Airy Road, Davidsonville, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Two-story house built on a large rural estate in a design at least inspired by the work of Downing and Davis. Constructed about 1850. Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from the unheated quarter to the second floor of the house.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Armature in exterior decorative plasterwork
location: St. James Goose Creek Parish Chu
headline: St. James Goose Creek Parish Church, 100 Parish Lane, Goose Creek, Berkeley County, South Carolina
description: Built 1708-19. Repaired after the earthquake of 1886 and after Hurricane Hugo in 1989. The original roof was largely rebuilt seemingly in the late 18th century reusing some of the original timbers reset for different functions. Principal rafter roof without tie beams. Decorative plaster ornament from the front gable of the chuirch of a pelican plucking her feathers to feed her young came down after the earthquake and was redone. Unclear whetehr this is the replacement one or the original. Note the brass araiture (perhaps suggesting it is later).
creator: Willie Graham

title: Copy of the 15th-century wooden original by Berndt Notke
location: St. George and the Dragon sculpt
headline: St. George and the Dragon sculpture, Köpmantorget (Merchants' Street), GamlaSstan, Stockholm, Sweden
description: Saint George and The Dragon sculpture (St Göran och Draken); sculptor of wooden original: Berndt Notke (1440-1509) Cast by: Moulded by Otto Meyer. Date Unveiled: October 10th, 1912 on the 441st anniversary of the battle of Brunkeberg between the Swedish regent Sten Sture and the Danish King Kristian I. Sculpture is a bronze copy of the original oak statue, which is standing inside the Stockholm Cathedral.

headline: Newington Stone Building King and Queen County Virginia
description: Newington Stone Building King and Queen County Virginia. Made of ballast stone, mix of sandstone from Cumbria area and limestone from southern England, including Portland stone, probably dates to the 18th century. Mixture of stone from Cumbria area of England (sandstone) and limestone from southern England. Shows evidence of heavy weathering before use in wall--all suggestive of being ballast stone reused for wall material. Clay mortar with lime and large pieces of oyster shell. Bricks form doorway, made of several different kinds of brick, all seemingly manufactured in England, suggestive of being brough over as ballast.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Header-bond church seen across the cemetery
headline: St. James, Lothian, 5757 Solomons Island Road, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Built 1763; porch tower likely original construction; church remodeled mid 19th century. Mollie Ridout notes: Col. John Weems was the builder/contractor who oversaw the construction of the church. He owned 4 or 5 properties including Burrage’s End near the traffic circle in Harwood. All sold to pay debts when he died.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Glazed header Flemish bond detail of 1745 house; hidden by 1835
headline: Four Mile Tree, 7741 Swanns Point Road, Spring Grove, Surry County, Virginia
description: Trees cut to build the house between the summer of 1743 and the winter of 1744/45. Seemingly completed in 1745. The parlor was remodeled in 1796 (dendro spring 1796); Phillip St. George Cocke remdeled the house in 1835. Photo shows ghost evidence of previous porch
creator: Willie Graham

description: Built 1764-65 by John Ridout. Detail of parlor mantel. 19th-century black paint removed in early 1950s to reveal this painted tablet
creator: Willie Graham

title: Interior
headline: Ellerslie, Bacon's Castle Trail, Surry County, Virginia
description: Two-story frame house, center passage plan. Mix of hand-forged wrought-iron nails and double struck machine cut nails. Lath nails are cut with flat heads. Riven lath. Georgian-style moldings. Cast-iron butt hinges except for a pair of H hinges on door under stair. CLosed string stair with square balusters. Thin muntins. Wainscot in most rooms--mix of flat, recessed panels and raised panels. Double chimneys on both ends connected to each other but pierced with a central window on the first floor and a cellar entry on the east side.3/1 American bond foundations and chimney. Hewn and pit sawn timbers; gauged and undercut flooring. c. 1805. Front, east dining room. Note original lighted niche set between chimneys. Mantel replaced c. 1860-75
creator: Willie Graham

title: Gable end of original wing as bricked up about 1730
headline: Holly Hill, 338 Friendship Road, Friendship, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Built as a timber-frame dwelling from timbers cut in 1698; expanded in 1713 (also a dendro date). Brick T added as final phase of Samuel Harrison's work, the expansion recorded in a painting he commissioned before his death in 1733. At the same time, Harrison bricked the front face and gable end of the original wing and its extension. Image of the glazed header Flemsih bond gable.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Service wing from the rear
headline: Indian Range, 1012 Mount Airy Road, Davidsonville, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Two-story house built on a large rural estate in a design at least inspired by the work of Downing and Davis. Constructed about 1850. Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from the unheated quarter to the second floor of the house.

headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham

title: Guaged-and-rubbed work of the frontispiece
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: church,brick,masonry,david minetree,minetree,all glazed header,flemish,flemish bond,header,glazed header,frontispiece,pediment,restored,rubbed brick,rubbed,gauged,gauged brick,gauged and rubbed brick

title: Open string staircase
headline: Ellerslie, Bacon's Castle Trail, Surry County, Virginia
description: Two-story frame house, center passage plan. Mix of hand-forged wrought-iron nails and double struck machine cut nails. Lath nails are cut with flat heads. Riven lath. Georgian-style moldings. Cast-iron butt hinges except for a pair of H hinges on door under stair. CLosed string stair with square balusters. Thin muntins. Wainscot in most rooms--mix of flat, recessed panels and raised panels. Double chimneys on both ends connected to each other but pierced with a central window on the first floor and a cellar entry on the east side.3/1 American bond foundations and chimney. Hewn and pit sawn timbers; gauged and undercut flooring. c. 1805
creator: Willie Graham

title: 1654 almshouse on alley
location: House of Our Lady of Woes
headline: House of Our Lady of Seven Woes, Driekroezenstraat 2-8, Bruge, West Flanders, Belgium
description: Former almshouses seemingly constructed in 1654. Located on the corner with Oude Gentweg 8. Former alms house O.-L.-V. VAN DE ZEVEN WEEËN / 1654 see painted inscription. Existing houses purchased in 1653 by founders Maria de Damhouder and Joost van der Straeten and furnished as a house of worship in 1654-1655, see partly weathered gable stone with (almost illegible) date 1654 as the keystone of the door frame. In 1951: adaptation of the original, high-placed windows to the current ones. 1979: conversion of houses into four residential units by architect E. Vyncke. https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/81852
creator: Willie Graham
categories: almshouse,poor house,godshuis,alley,alleyway,gable,cross gable,stepped gable,tie,wall tie,brick,masonry,dwelling,dutch gable

Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from the unheated quarter to the second floor of the house. Photo of early pry bar discovered in the roof frame under the shingles
creator: Willie Graham

headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham
categories: rococco,georgian,classical,5 part house,dwelling,house,plantation,sharpe horation sharpe,gov. sharpe,brick,masonry,water table,molded,flemish bond

title: Brick detail
headline: Ellerslie, Bacon's Castle Trail, Surry County, Virginia
description: Two-story frame house, center passage plan. Mix of hand-forged wrought-iron nails and double struck machine cut nails. Lath nails are cut with flat heads. Riven lath. Georgian-style moldings. Cast-iron butt hinges except for a pair of H hinges on door under stair. CLosed string stair with square balusters. Thin muntins. Wainscot in most rooms--mix of flat, recessed panels and raised panels. Double chimneys on both ends connected to each other but pierced with a central window on the first floor and a cellar entry on the east side.3/1 American bond foundations and chimney. Hewn and pit sawn timbers; gauged and undercut flooring. c. 1805. Chimney brickwork painted red at an early date and later whitewashed
creator: Willie Graham

headline: Skogaholms Manor, Skansen, Djurgårdsslätten 49-51, 115 21 Stockholm, Sweden
creator: Willie Graham

title: H hinges used as butt recreated based on ghost of original; 1769
headline: Cloverfields, 500 Forman Landing Road, Queenstown, Queen Anne's County, Maryland
description: Built 1705; expanded 1728; rear rooms raised two stories in 1750s; roof of rear converted to a shed in 1761; house renovated in 1769; heavily remodeled in the 1840s; remodeled again in 1912. restored 2018-2021. Door to parlor. Original 1769 jamb; reproduction hinge and door
creator: Willie Graham

title: Mattaponi Baptist Church
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.Some joints in this image are faked; ohers are hidden using a mix of hide glue and brick dust
creator: Willie Graham
categories: church,brick,masonry,david minetree,minetree,segmental pediment,frontispiece,gauged,rubbed,gauged and rubbed,hide glue,brick dust

headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham

title: Drawing room
headline: Indian Range, 1012 Mount Airy Road, Davidsonville, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Two-story house built on a large rural estate in a design at least inspired by the work of Downing and Davis. Constructed about 1850. Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from the unheated quarter to the second floor of the house.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Chief's House, built about 1885, before restoration
headline: Chief's House, Sunnyside Road, St. Stephen's Church Vicinity, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Built about 1885 as a two-room, board-and-batten structure. Weatherboard, detached, frame kitchen built soon thereafter. About 1920 the kitchen was expanded and a front added tothe house, which connected it to the kitchen. Attic over original kitchen. Note the lack of collars but the use of a wind brace
creator: Willie Graham

title: Detail of yellow brick on ca. 1730 wing
headline: Holly Hill, 338 Friendship Road, Friendship, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Built as a timber-frame dwelling from timbers cut in 1698; expanded in 1713 (also a dendro date). Brick T added as final phase of Samuel Harrison's work, the expansion recorded in a painting he commissioned before his death in 1733. At the same time, Harrison bricked the front face and gable end of the original wing and its extension. Yellow brick on rear of ca. 1730 wing

title: Although rubbed, hammer percussion marks remain visible on quoin
headline: All Hallows Parish Church, 3600 Solomons Island Road, Edgewater, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Built  1727; altered c. 1825; 1885; burned and rebuilt, 1940. Original brick porch on south; original vestry room on west. Door also on north opposite main south door but filled in in the 19th century. Note the percusive hammer marks on the bevel of the quoins that was not fully rubbed out. Rubbing done in place. Note the cut to simulate closer in body brick but then not completed with lime putty.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: church,brick,masonry,quoin,hammer,hammer mark,rub,quage,cut and rub,gauge and rub,tool mark

title: Chimney with pent between, built about 1805
headline: Ellerslie, Bacon's Castle Trail, Surry County, Virginia
description: Two-story frame house, center passage plan. Mix of hand-forged wrought-iron nails and double struck machine cut nails. Lath nails are cut with flat heads. Riven lath. Georgian-style moldings. Cast-iron butt hinges except for a pair of H hinges on door under stair. Closed string stair with square balusters. Thin muntins. Wainscot in most rooms--mix of flat, recessed panels and raised panels. Double chimneys on both ends connected to each other but pierced with a central window on the first floor and a cellar entry on the east side.3/1 American bond foundations and chimney. Hewn and pit sawn timbers; gauged and undercut flooring. c. 1805. Chimney brickwork painted red at an early date and later whitewashed
creator: Willie Graham

title: Cast-iron butt hinges secured with rose head nails; ca. 1805
headline: Ellerslie, Bacon's Castle Trail, Surry County, Virginia
description: Two-story frame house, center passage plan. Mix of hand-forged wrought-iron nails and double struck machine cut nails. Lath nails are cut with flat heads. Riven lath. Georgian-style moldings. Cast-iron butt hinges except for a pair of H hinges on door under stair. CLosed string stair with square balusters. Thin muntins. title: 1654 almshouse on alley
location: House of Our Lady of Woes
headline: House of Our Lady of Seven Woes, Driekroezenstraat 2-8, Bruge, West Flanders, Belgium
description: Former almshouses seemingly constructed in 1654. Located on the corner with Oude Gentweg 8. Former alms house O.-L.-V. VAN DE ZEVEN WEEËN / 1654 see painted inscription. Existing houses purchased in 1653 by founders Maria de Damhouder and Joost van der Straeten and furnished as a house of worship in 1654-1655, see partly weathered gable stone with (almost illegible) date 1654 as the keystone of the door frame. In 1951: adaptation of the original, high-placed windows to the current ones. 1979: conversion of houses into four residential units by architect E. Vyncke. https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/81852
creator: Willie Graham

headline: Riddarholmen Church, Birger Jarls Torg 2, 112 28, Stockholm, Sweden
description: From Wikipedia: Riddarholmen Church (Swedish: Riddarholmskyrkan) is the church of the former medieval Greyfriars Monastery in Stockholm, Sweden. The church serves as the final resting place of most Swedish monarchs. Riddarholmen Church is located on the island of Riddarholmen, close to the Royal Palace in Stockholm, Sweden. The congregation was dissolved in 1807 and today the church is used only for burial and commemorative purposes. Swedish monarchs from Gustavus Adolphus (d. 1632 AD) to Gustaf V (d. 1950) are entombed here (with only one exception: Queen Christina who is buried within St. Peter's Basilica in Rome), as well as the earlier monarchs Magnus III (d. 1290) and Charles VIII (d. 1470). It has been discontinued as a royal burial site in favor of the Royal Cemetery and today is run by departments of the Swedish Government and Royal Court. It is one of the oldest buildings in Stockholm, parts of it dating to the late-13th century, when it was built as a greyfriars monastery. After the Protestant Reformation, the monastery was closed and the building became a Lutheran church. A spire designed by Flemish architect Willem Boy (1520–1592) was added during the reign of John III, but it was destroyed by a lightning strike on July 28, 1835, after which it was replaced with the present cast-iron spire.  Coats of arms of knights of the Royal Order of the Seraphim are on the walls of the church. When a knight of the Order dies, his coat of arms is hung in the church and when the funeral takes place the church's bells are rung without pause from 12:00 to 13:00.
creator: Willie Graham

headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. title: Interior
headline: Ellerslie, Bacon's Castle Trail, Surry County, Virginia
description: Two-story frame house, center passage plan. Mix of hand-forged wrought-iron nails and double struck machine cut nails. Lath nails are cut with flat heads. Riven lath. Georgian-style moldings. Cast-iron butt hinges except for a pair of H hinges on door under stair. CLosed string stair with square balusters. Thin muntins. Wainscot in most rooms--mix of flat, recessed panels and raised panels. Double chimneys on both ends connected to each other but pierced with a central window on the first floor and a cellar entry on the east side.3/1 American bond foundations and chimney. Hewn and pit sawn timbers; gauged and undercut flooring. c. 1805. Rear, west first-floor room. Door to front parlor cut in 20th century.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Gauged-and-rubbed work on the frontispiece
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham

Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Sconce
headline: Gripsholm Castle, 647 31 Mariefred, Södermanland, Sweden
description: From Wikipedia: In 1773, Gripsholm Castle was renovated by King Gustav III,[8] on behalf of his consort Sophia Magdalena. The castle was frequently used by the royal court during the reign of Gustav III, who favored it and spent several months there every year. The perhaps most famous addition to the castle during his reign was a theater, which was added in one of the castle towers. It was the stage for both the amateur theatre of the royal court as well as The French Theater of Gustav III in 1781–1792. After the Coup of 1809, Gustav IV Adolf and his family were also imprisoned in the castle after his deposition from the throne. He had to sign his abdication document there. 1701 date on interior of chapel
creator: Willie Graham

title: Garnet-headed newel post in service wing
headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham

title: 1850s country house inspired by Davis and Downing
headline: Indian Range, 1012 Mount Airy Road, Davidsonville, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Two-story house built on a large rural estate in a design at least inspired by the work of Downing and Davis. Constructed about 1850. Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from teh unheated quarter to the second floor of the house.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Hand-forged strap hinge with reverse eye
headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham

title: Gauged-and-rubbed work on the frontispiece
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham

title: 1654 almshouse on alley
location: House of Our Lady of Woes
headline: House of Our Lady of Seven Woes, Driekroezenstraat 2-8, Bruge, West Flanders, Belgium
description: Former almshouses seemingly constructed in 1654. Located on the corner with Oude Gentweg 8. Former alms house O.-L.-V. VAN DE ZEVEN WEEËN / 1654 see painted inscription. Existing houses purchased in 1653 by founders Maria de Damhouder and Joost van der Straeten and furnished as a house of worship in 1654-1655, see partly weathered gable stone with (almost illegible) date 1654 as the keystone of the door frame. In 1951: adaptation of the original, high-placed windows to the current ones. 1979: conversion of houses into four residential units by architect E. Vyncke. https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/81852
creator: Willie Graham
categories: almshouse,poor house,godshuis,alley,alleyway,gable,cross gable,stepped gable,tie,wall tie,brick,masonry,dwelling,dutch gable

title: Kitchen with remains of early stove
headline: Indian Range, 1012 Mount Airy Road, Davidsonville, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Two-story house built on a large rural estate in a design at least inspired by the work of Downing and Davis. Constructed about 1850. Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from the unheated quarter to the second floor of the house. Leibrandt & McDowell Stove Company. Philadelphia & Baltimore.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: house,dwelling,a j davis,downing,davis and downing,frame,timber frame,gothic,kitchen,service,service wing,gothic revival,stove,leibrandt & mcdowell stove company,cast iron,cook,cokking,service

title: Console with date Anno 1701 in chapel
headline: Gripsholm Castle, 647 31 Mariefred, Södermanland, Sweden
description: From Wikipedia: In 1773, Gripsholm Castle was renovated by King Gustav III,[8] on behalf of his consort Sophia Magdalena. The castle was frequently used by the royal court during the reign of Gustav III, who favored it and spent several months there every year. The perhaps most famous addition to the castle during his reign was a theater, which was added in one of the castle towers. It was the stage for both the amateur theatre of the royal court as well as The French Theater of Gustav III in 1781–1792. After the Coup of 1809, Gustav IV Adolf and his family were also imprisoned in the castle after his deposition from the throne. He had to sign his abdication document there. 1701 date on pulpit.
creator: Willie Graham

title: Mattaponi Baptist Church
headline: Mattaponi Baptist Church, Stevensville, King and Queen County, Virginia
description: Constructed began on a new lower church for St. Stephen's Parish in 1730 and was finished about 1734. Built by David Minetree, who incuded his name in a brick mounted near teh east doorway, along with one that presently reads WL but was first made as WN. The N was filled in with hide glue and brick dust and the new L carved over it presumably during original construction. All-glazed header Flemish bond with compass-headed windows and three gauged-and-rubbed frontispieces. The church burned in the early 20th century and so only the brick shell survives. Ray Cannetti, Kevin Nito and Robert Hall are presently restoring the frontispieces.
creator: Willie Graham

title: 1654 almshouse on alley
location: House of Our Lady of Woes
headline: House of Our Lady of Seven Woes, Driekroezenstraat 2-8, Bruge, West Flanders, Belgium
description: Former almshouses seemingly constructed in 1654. Located on the corner with Oude Gentweg 8. Former alms house O.-L.-V. VAN DE ZEVEN WEEËN / 1654 see painted inscription. Existing houses purchased in 1653 by founders Maria de Damhouder and Joost van der Straeten and furnished as a house of worship in 1654-1655, see partly weathered gable stone with (almost illegible) date 1654 as the keystone of the door frame. In 1951: adaptation of the original, high-placed windows to the current ones. 1979: conversion of houses into four residential units by architect E. Vyncke. https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/81852
creator: Willie Graham
categories: almshouse,poor house,godshuis,alley,alleyway,gable,cross gable,stepped gable,tie,wall tie,brick,masonry,dwelling,dutch gable

title: 18th-c handmade rim lock
headline: Whitehall, 1915 Whitehall Road, Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Gov. Horatio Sharpe built Whitehall as a party or banqueting house in the 1760s. Some original design drawings survive, possibly from the hands of Joseph Horatio Anderson who later undertook construction of the Maryland State House. These drawings show the house partially as built but also with features that were not realized until the 20th century. Anderson drafted an octagonal stable, which was reportedly erected.  Dendro (Worhington) for the original build dates to the winter of 1764/65. That work included the main block, with a central cubed room flanked by one story wings. All three rooms were intended as entertaining spaces. The central hall has a vaulted ceiling with elaborate rococo plasterwork and heavily carved woodwork around the walls, doors, and windows. Some of the applied carvings to the walls are original, but heavily repaired in the 1950s. Plasterwork in the cove ceiling was also restored and elaborated at this time. (I presume the central ceiling medallion was wholly made up in the 1950s and that the original treatment is long lost.) The center hall has exquisite, full-length yellow pine flooring and no evidence of carpeting. The flanking rooms probably served as dining room and a parlor-like space. Both are heated, have plaster cornices, and have heavily carved woodwork. These rooms received several generations of carpeting. Since the quality of their flooring was less than the hall, they might have been fitted with them from the outset. The house was intended for entertainments and little accommodation was made for overnight guests, giving the structure a banqueting house like feel, albeit it without cellar service spaces (where the kitchen was placed is unknown for this original construction.) A basement story was created underneath with a passage and two vaulted rooms (probably at least one used for wet storage). Flanking them are two private family chambers. One undoubtedly served as a dining room and has an original beaufat (although its lo
creator: Willie Graham

title: Rear wall of kitchen
headline: Indian Range, 1012 Mount Airy Road, Davidsonville, Anne Arundel County, Maryland
description: Two-story house built on a large rural estate in a design at least inspired by the work of Downing and Davis. Constructed about 1850. Center-passage plan with drawing room on one side of the passage and dining room and library on the other. Rear/side service wing includes intermediate space possibly for staging food, carriage house, and kitchen on the extreme end. Two quarters in the attic above the carriage house and kitchen--one heated with a stove, the other not. Passage leads from the unheated quarter to the second floor of the house.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: house,dwelling,a j davis,downing,davis and downing,frame,timber frame,gothic,kitchen,service,service wing,gothic revival

title: Street entry to complex
headline: God Houses of Hertsberge (Godshuis Hertsberge), Katelijnestraat 83-91, Bruge, West Flanders, Belgium
description: The God houses of Hertsberge in Bruges. A God House is a charity where the sick and elderly were cared for in the name of God. There are only a few archive notes about the God House Hertsberge in Bruges. Located outside the neighboring beguinage, the Godshuis was originally a convent for poor beguines. A charter states that the convent was founded in 1335 by Griele and Marzoete van Herdsberghe./ That's where the houses probably got their name from. The Hertsberge houses may have evolved into God's houses for impoverished elderly women in the course of the late 14th and at the beginning of the 15th century./ The God Houses consist of seven typical single-story little houses with dot-facade and on the top an arc-opening, each with a Tudor or Cork Bowl door and only one window. The houses have their own chapel./In 1796, when Belgium was under French occupation, the French government placed the god house, like almost all of the city's caritative institutions, under a new board, the Civilian Houses of Commons. An organization to help the poor and the sick. Since 1974, the God houses are protected as a national monument.
creator: Willie Graham

creator: Willie Graham

title: Courtyard
headline: Gripsholm Castle, 647 31 Mariefred, Södermanland, Sweden
description: From Wikipedia: In 1773, Gripsholm Castle was renovated by King Gustav III,[8] on behalf of his consort Sophia Magdalena. The castle was frequently used by the royal court during the reign of Gustav III, who favored it and spent several months there every year. The perhaps most famous addition to the castle during his reign was a theater, which was added in one of the castle towers. It was the stage for both the amateur theatre of the royal court as well as The French Theater of Gustav III in 1781–1792. After the Coup of 1809, Gustav IV Adolf and his family were also imprisoned in the castle after his deposition from the throne. He had to sign his abdication document there.
creator: Willie Graham
